channel.title: Bloomberg Economics

item.title: Boston Tax Hit From Office Market Slump Swells to $1.7 Billion
item.description: Boston’s office buildings stand to lose nearly half their value over five years, costing the city as much as $1.7 billion in cumulative tax revenue.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ryan

media:content.media:description: Office buildings in Downtown Boston, Massachusetts, US.

item.title: AI Can Help Predict Inflation, Bank of England’s Greene Says
item.description: The Bank of England is experimenting with artificial intelligence to help forecast inflation and hone its communications, according to rate-setter Megan Greene.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Megan Greene Photographer: Betty Laura Zapata/Bloomberg

item.title: Data Error Pushed Up UK Inflation in April, ONS Says
item.description: Britain’s statistics agency said it overstated the official inflation rate due to a mistake in numbers it was given on vehicle taxes, the latest in a string of errors to plague the country’s economic data.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Vehicles on the production line in the UK.

item.title: EU Gets Court Boost in Right to Retaliate Against Trump Tariffs
item.description: The European Union’s power to impose retaliatory tariffs on US goods and services won a legal boost from an adviser to the bloc’s top court, as the 27-member jurisdiction continues to spar with President Donald Trump over trade.
item.dc:creator: Samuel Stolton

media:content.media:description: Zippo lighters at the company's plant in Bradford, Pennsylvania, US.

item.title: UK Builders Shed Jobs at Pace Seen After Global Financial Crisis
item.description: Payrolls in the UK construction industry shrank at a pace last seen in 2010, when excluding the pandemic, according to a survey that casts doubt over the Labour government’s ambition for a building boom.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: A construction worker on a residential site in London. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: RBI Set to Deliver Another Rate Cut to Lift Growth: Guide
item.description: India’s central bank will likely cut interest rates for the third straight meeting to boost economic growth, with market watchers focused on the extent of easing in this cycle.
item.dc:creator: Anup Roy, Subhadip Sircar

item.title: Sweden’s Core Inflation Slowdown Backs June Rate Cut
item.description: Sweden’s underlying inflation rate fell to a five-month low, broadly in line with expectations and strengthening the case for the Riksbank to reduce interest rates later this month.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Duxbury

media:content.media:description: Shoppers walk along Drottninggatan in Stockholm. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

item.title: OECD Backs SARB Push to Lower South Africa’s Inflation Target
item.description: Lowering South Africa’s inflation target would drive economic growth and international competitiveness, said the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, echoing the country’s central bank.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: Enoch Godongwana.

item.title: Spain Makes First Payment in Lengthy Renewable Energy Fight
item.description: The Spanish government made its first payment as a result of an arbitration decision in 2021 around the country’s move to change investor incentives tied to renewable energy projects, following a number of lengthy legal battles between Spain and various creditors.
item.dc:creator: Irene Garcia Perez

media:content.media:description: Wind turbines and electricity power lines in Zaragoza, Spain, on Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025. Europe’s top renewable energy developer has focused the bulk of its investments on grid projects in the US, UK and other global markets — a business that has performed well. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

item.title: Vietnam Sends Trade Demand Reply as US Turns Up China Heat
item.description: Vietnam said it is responding to US demands with “goodwill” and has sent a written reply to US trade requests after the Trump administration vowed to keep pressuring the Southeast Asian nation to reduce its role in China supply chains.
item.dc:creator: Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen, Francesca Stevens

item.title: German Factory Orders Rose Even After US Tariff Announcement
item.description: German factory orders kept rising after President Donald Trump’s announcement of US reciprocal tariffs, defying expectations for a setback.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

item.title: China’s Services Activity Picked Up After Truce in Trade War
item.description: China’s services activity expanded at a faster pace in May, a private survey showed, in a sign the consumer economy is stabilizing while higher US tariffs threaten demand for exports.
item.dc:creator: Lucille Liu

media:content.media:description: Shoppers pass stores in the Nanjing Road West shopping area in Shanghai, China, on Sunday, March 2, 2025. President Xi Jinping heads into China's biggest political huddle of the year with his economy finally getting back some swagger. Photographer: Raul Ariano/Bloomberg

item.title: Germany’s Got a Problem, and It’s More Than Donald Trump
item.description: As Donald Trump pushes ahead with his campaign to transform the way the world does business, Germany is uniquely vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow, Marilen Martin

media:content.media:description: A viewing point looking out over the Schwelgern coking plant at ThyssenKrupp’s Duisburg steelworks in April.

item.title: ECB to Cut Rates as Trade Mess Weighs on the Economy
item.description: The European Central Bank is set to lower interest rates for an eighth time as President Donald Trump’s jolts to global trade dim the prospects for inflation and the economy.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow

item.title: US Business Optimism Slumps in ‘Clear Pivot’ From Trump Election
item.description: US business optimism has moved sharply lower, deepening a trend seen in the first quarter and marking a sharp reversal from the buoyant mood among executives after Donald Trump’s reelection as president.
item.dc:creator: Nina Trentmann

item.title: Why Trump Has Doubled Down on Steel and Aluminum Tariffs
item.description: President Donald Trump raised levies on US imports of steel and aluminum to 50% from 25% as he ratcheted up his campaign to reshape the country’s trade ties with the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Martin Ritchie, Jessica Zhou

media:content.media:description: Sheet aluminum. Photographer: Oliver Bunic/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Stymied in ‘Art of the Deal’ Approach to World’s Strongmen
item.description: President Donald Trump has long boasted about his ability to cut deals with the world’s strongmen. But now that he’s back in the White House, his charms haven’t worked on the leaders he professes to admire.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Drozdiak, Courtney McBride

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump Photographer: Eric Lee/Bloomberg

item.title: Australia’s Spending Stays Soft as Consumers Wait for Sales
item.description: Australia’s household spending remained tepid in April as consumers directed their spare cash to services like eating out rather than goods such as clothing and cars.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Japan to Seek Tariff Review in Latest Negotiations Ahead of G-7
item.description: Japan will stick to its stance of seeking a review of all US tariffs in what could be the final ministerial-level talks ahead of a leaders’ summit this month, the nation’s top trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa said.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa, Japan's economic revitalization minster, speaks to members of the media at the Japanese embassy in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, May 1, 2025. Akazawa is in Washington for a second round of talks this week with his US counterparts, as countries around the world watch to see where the negotiations end up. Photographer: Stefani Reynolds/Bloomberg

item.title: The Rare-Earth Fight Imperiling US-China Trade Peace, Explained
item.description: Markets cheered in early May when the US and China agreed in Geneva to lower tariffs and other barriers. But after a few weeks, the shine started to come off that deal, with China accusing the US of violating it with new restrictions and the US saying China failed to honor promises on rare earths.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

media:content.media:description: Neodymium is displayed at the Inner Mongolia Baotou Steel Rare-Earth Hi-Tech Co. factory in Baotou, Inner Mongolia, China, on Wednesday, May 5, 2010. A generation after Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping made mastering neodymium and 16 other elements known as rare-earths a priority, China has cornered the market, with far-reaching effects ranging from job losses and global trade to U.S. national security.

item.title: Why Golden Visas Are Quietly Making a Comeback
item.description: On this week’s Australia Podcast: Host Rebecca Jones speaks to wealth editor Ainsley Thomson about why New Zealand is embracing golden visas — and wealthy expats.

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians cross a bridge as the Sky Tower and other buildings stand in the background in Auckland, New Zealand, on Saturday, Feb. 22, 2025. New Zealand’s central bank will slow the pace of interest-rate cuts after a third straight reduction of 50 basis points, saying lower borrowing costs should begin to stoke an economic recovery.

item.title: Japan’s Base Pay Grows Faster, Backing BOJ Rate Hike Case
item.description: Growth in Japanese workers’ base pay picked up as annual wage hikes began to kick in, in a positive development for the Bank of Japan as authorities look for an opportunity to raise interest rates even as domestic and global economic risks mount.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: China’s Power Prices Nosedive in Relief to Tariff-Hit Factories
item.description: A crash in Chinese coal prices, and a flood of clean energy, are cutting power rates in major industrial hubs, easing pressure on some of the factories caught in the crossfire of trade hostilities with the US.
item.dc:creator: Dan Murtaugh, Kathy Chen

item.title: Kashkari Says Fed Well Positioned to Wait for Tariff Impact
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari said the US central bank is well positioned to wait and see how tariff policies impact the economy before adjusting interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Neel Kashkari

item.title: UK Home Sales Hit Three-Year High, Defying Slowdown Fears
item.description: Britain’s property market saw its busiest month in over three years in May, defying expectations for a slowdown after a tax break for buyers expired.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Estate agent "Sold" signs outside residential properties in London, UK, on Thursday, June 30, 2022. UK house prices slowed more than expected this month after a series of interest-rate increases raised the cost of mortgages. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

item.title: Bowman Confirmed by Senate to be Fed Vice Chair for Supervision
item.description: Federal Reserve Governor Michelle Bowman was confirmed by the US Senate on Wednesday to serve as the central bank’s vice chair for supervision, further signaling a shift to lighter regulation under President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Katanga Johnson

media:content.media:description: Michelle Bowman, a Fed governor

item.title: Why the Trade War Is Keeping US Inflation Down—For Now
item.description: On this week’s episode of Trumponomics, we discuss consumer pessimism and how legal challenges to Donald Trump’s tariffs might play out.
item.dc:creator: Sommer Saadi, Stephanie Flanders

media:content.media:description: MIAMI, FLORIDA - JANUARY 12: Edwin Lopez sorts the money in the cash register at Frankie's Pizza on January 12, 2022 in Miami, Florida. The eatery's co-owner, Renee Pasquarella, said the cost for everything needed to run the business — from cardboard boxes to pizza ingredients including cheese, tomatoes, meat — has gone up. She said that in the 67 years the pizza place has been serving customers this has been one of the toughest times to keep it open. The Labor Department released a report indicating that the consumer price index rose 7 percent in December, compared to a year ago, the fastest increase since June 1982. (Photo by Joe Raedle/Getty Images)

item.title: Trump Budget Plan Raises Concern Over Cuts to Statistics Bureau
item.description: The Trump administration is proposing to cut resources from the Bureau of Labor Statistics when the agency is already reeling from years of budget constraints, further compounding concerns about the quality and quantity of data produced about the US economy.
item.dc:creator: Molly Smith

media:content.media:description: Attendees wait in line to enter a career fair in Sacramento, California.

item.title: Trump Gets a Tentative Win From CBO's New Tax and Tariff Estimates
item.description: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office handed Republicans a major political talking point Wednesday, with projections that showed the possibility for President Donald Trump’s tariffs to bring in more federal revenue than will be lost by his giant tax-cut plan.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump

item.title: Carney Holds Back on Tariff Retaliation, Says US-Canada Talks Are Progressing
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney said Canada and the US are in “intensive” talks about the countries’ trade relationship, explaining his government’s decision not to respond yet to the Trump administration’s doubling of steel and aluminum tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt, Mathieu Dion

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada’s prime minister.
